Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stared at the email from my project manager, the subject line flashing red urgency: “Client Delivery—Critical Path.” My task was the last piece before the handoff, and the deadline was today. I’d promised my team I’d have it done, and I knew the client was waiting. But I was standing in the middle of the polling station, ballot envelope in hand, when the poll worker frowned and slid it back to me. “I’m sorry, but the signature smudged. Please re-sign so your vote counts.” I glanced at the clock—if I left now, I could make it back to my desk and finish the task before the deadline. But the poll worker’s eyes were kind but firm, and the instructions were clear: follow the process, make sure your vote is valid. My phone buzzed again in my pocket, another reminder from my team. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between my responsibility to my colleagues and my duty as a voter. My hand hovered over the pen, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both demanded my full attention.
